captions.text: *INTRO MUSIC*

So we did the samurai movie plot in Trek
to Yomi, in which the protagonist

watches their mentor get killed as a child
and then trains for years before going

flip-out spanky-wanky all over the
baddies responsible and eventually

concluding that revenge isn&#39;t really worth
it, now let&#39;s turn to Sifu and explore

instead the martial arts movie plot, in
which the protagonist watches their

mentor get killed as a child and then
trains for years before going flip-out

spanky-wanky all over the baddies
responsible and eventually concluding

that revenge isn&#39;t really worth it, while not
wearing a pointy hat. And sometimes

even manages to get through the whole 
process inside a century, Shenmue. Sifu is

a third person brawler that came out a
while back but holy Jesus human

centipeding Christ are new releases
dead right now. They&#39;re so fucking dead they&#39;re

planning to start their comeback tour in
Sarajevo. It&#39;s not usually this bad this time

of year. I think Elden Ring might&#39;ve
frightened everything off. It&#39;s like how it&#39;s

easy to lose confidence in your stand-up
set if the opening act was a gigantic

golden dancing rhinoceros that spunked
diamonds at ballistic velocity and killed

eleven audience members. But anyway,
I&#39;d been getting requests for Sifu and

finally had the chance to play through it
last week, and I&#39;d have to say it is an

interesting game. You play a young
martial artist who as a child watched

their mentor get killed and who then
trains for years before going flip-out

spanky-wa - oh hang on that&#39;s not very
interesting at all. Okay, so it&#39;s a game

where you go through a sequence of
levels based on urban settings where

every single person you meet from junkies
to janitors to businessmen to substitute

maths teachers is trained to the exact
same standard in one highly specific

martial art, except for the fat ones who
all learned grappling techniques from

handling their enormous sandwiches - oh
wait that&#39;s not very interesting either,

that&#39;s just the bog standard retro arcade
brawler template. It even ends each level

with a colourful boss and litters the
environment with disposable melee

weapons because apparently the only
things people throw away in this world

are beer bottles, broom handles and
fileting knives. I guess it&#39;s pretty

interesting that it&#39;s being done in 3D over
the shoulder style, although it does on

one or two occasions switch to a 2D side
on camera when it starts to fret that the

reference might be going over peoples&#39;
heads. The first interesting bit is the

gameplay mechanic wherein every time
your character dies from getting kung-

fued too much - which will happen
frequently because the basic combat

also borrows from the retro arcade
gaming tradition of being designed to

remove coins from the pockets of
unsupervised schoolchildren with all the

fervor of the CIA removing democracy
from an easily bullied oil-rich South

American country - then they
immediately come back to life, but age an

entire year. So you start out as a fresh
faced Disney prince in his school jogging

trousers and death by death watch his
beard grow and his muscles fill out until

by the end he&#39;s about forty-six and looks
like an overgrown ornamental rock

garden. It&#39;s an interesting storytelling
concept, really drives home the main

character&#39;s obsession if he&#39;s willing to
waste an entire puberty bringing down

one troublesome boss fight, but in
practical terms it&#39;s not much more than a

classic lives system with a hard limit.
There&#39;s a couple of associated gimmicks,

as you age your health goes down but
your damage goes up, but otherwise you

might as well put it out of your mind. I
mean, on my first attempt I was stressing

out restarting the first level over and over
again when I was dying too many times

because much the same reason I gave up
binge drinking, I didn&#39;t want to waste my

twenties. But eventually I learned to relax
and go with the flow. The flow of being

killed, because it&#39;s not a long game and
forty-fifty odd lives is more than enough,

frankly, and at points you can even spend
XP on rolling your age back a few years if

it bothers you that much, although that
kinda defeats the message as I

interpreted it. &quot;Ooh, don&#39;t waste your
precious years on revenge because you&#39;ll

never get them back. Now, would you like
to spend some Sifu fun bucks on getting a

bunch of your years back?&quot; But it is a
game where you are expected to die a

certain amount. Combat&#39;s bloody hard to
get to grips with. It starts with your

standard light attack heavy attack
dodge block parry arrangement then

puts the whole thing in fast forward and
makes everyone get right up in each

other&#39;s elasticated waistbands. And the
trouble with the over the shoulder

perspective is that your attacks all have
about half as much range as you think

they do. Buy the snap kick as soon as you
can because that&#39;s about the best way to

close distance and otherwise your little
T-Rex arms will spend a lot of time

whirling through empty air ruffling 
veryone&#39;s ties and pocket squares. Also,

you&#39;re supposed to press up or down
while holding block to weave around

certain low and high attacks, but I&#39;d just
hold block and randomly wiggle the stick

about like an unruly clitoris and that&#39;d
have maybe a sixty percent success rate.

I guess I like the combat because it does
feel satisfying to take apart a roomful of

thugs like they&#39;re a mess of tangled
Christmas lights, and in the end that is the

whole point, to let us feel like the dude in
the martial arts movie going full flip-out

spanky wanky on a foolful of rooms. I
mean a roomful of fools. Sorry, can we

take a moment to appreciate that I only
invented the phrase &quot;flip-out spanky

wanky&quot; two minutes ago and yet its
meaning was already perfectly clear?

Demonstrates real articulacy, I think. If I
have a complaint for the combat system

I&#39;d say some kind of lock on would be nice
so when surrounded my dude doesn&#39;t just

randomly pick who he&#39;s going to start
windmilling at based on who&#39;s got the

least appealing facial hair or something. I
suppose when you boil it down Sifu isn&#39;t

much more than a level-based brawler
with a couple of gimmicks and a focus on

achieving mastery through repetition, the
story&#39;s not a huge draw because most of

the voice performance is going for
&quot;serious unflappable stoic&quot; but comes

across more like &quot;trying to escape a dull
conversation on the bus.&quot; But it also has a

visual stylishness that I think elevates it a
bit. The environments have an appealing

look and attention to detail that reminds
me of Hitman, at least until you&#39;ve turned

them into impromptu bowling alleys with
thugs for pins and box ottomans for balls.

There was one last disappointment in
store, and that&#39;s that there was a bad

ending and a good ending where to get
the good ending you have to do the boss

fights in an extra hard way that goes
against what the game&#39;s been teaching

you the whole time. You&#39;re supposed to
duff them up until the icon comes up that

says &quot;press X to split me open like a
naughty coin purse&quot; and then not do that.

Well geez, pardon me for being prompt.
Of course you get the bad ending for

killing bosses and the good ending for
sparing them because revenge is not the

answer blah de blah. Change the fucking
record. Why do we always get so

selectively judgey about killing people?
As I said to the arresting officer.
*OUTRO MUSIC*

Closed Captions by @willcblogs
